Literature Review: Long-read DNA sequencing (LRS) has emerged as a transformative technology in genomics, offering unprecedented insights into the complexities of human genetic variation. This literature review explores recent advances in LRS technologies, their applications in genomic research, and the remaining challenges in the field.LRS technologies have significantly expanded our ability to analyze large structural variations (SVs) and repetitive DNA sequences, which have been historically challenging to study using short-read sequencing methods. The two primary LRS platforms, Pacific Biosciences' Single Molecule Real-Time (SMRT) sequencing and Oxford Nanopore Technologies' nanopore sequencing, have enabled the generation of read lengths ranging from tens to hundreds of kilobases (Logsdon et al., 2020). This dramatic increase in read length has revolutionized our understanding of genomic architecture and variation.One of the most significant applications of LRS has been in the detection and characterization of SVs, including insertions, deletions, inversions, and translocations. Chaisson et al. (2019) demonstrated that LRS could identify over 20,000 SVs per human genome, many of which were previously undetectable using short-read sequencing. This enhanced ability to detect SVs has profound implications for understanding genetic diversity and identifying pathogenic mutations associated with various diseases.The capacity of LRS to resolve repetitive DNA regions has also been a game-changer in genomics. Repetitive sequences, which comprise a substantial portion of the human genome, have long been a challenge for short-read sequencing technologies. LRS has enabled the assembly and analysis of these regions, including satellite DNA, centromeres, and telomeres. In a landmark study, Nurk et al. (2022) reported the first complete, telomere-to-telomere assembly of a human genome, including previously unresolved regions such as acrocentric chromosome short arms and centromeres.Another significant advantage of LRS is its ability to provide long-range haplotype information. Wenger et al. (2019) demonstrated that LRS could generate highly accurate, phased de novo genome assemblies, allowing for the resolution of complex genomic regions and the determination of allele-specific expression patterns. This capability has important implications for understanding the functional consequences of genetic variations and their potential role in disease.LRS has also shown promise in the field of epigenetics. Both SMRT and nanopore sequencing can directly detect DNA modifications, such as methylation, without the need for bisulfite conversion or other chemical treatments (Simpson et al., 2017). This ability to simultaneously sequence DNA and detect epigenetic modifications provides a more comprehensive view of the genome and its regulation.In the clinical setting, LRS has demonstrated its potential for improving the diagnosis of genetic disorders. Merker et al. (2018) showed that LRS could identify pathogenic structural variants in patients with undiagnosed genetic disorders that were missed by short-read sequencing and microarray analysis. This highlights the potential of LRS to enhance the diagnostic yield in clinical genomics and provide more accurate genetic counseling.Despite these advances, several challenges remain in the widespread adoption and application of LRS technologies. One of the primary limitations is the higher error rate compared to short-read sequencing, particularly for nanopore sequencing. However, recent improvements in base-calling algorithms and the development of consensus sequencing approaches have significantly reduced error rates (Rang et al., 2018).Another challenge is the higher cost and lower throughput of LRS compared to short-read sequencing. While the cost per base has decreased significantly in recent years, it remains higher than that of short-read sequencing. Additionally, the computational resources required for analyzing long-read data are substantial, necessitating the development of more efficient bioinformatics tools and pipelines (De Coster et al., 2018).The application of LRS in large-scale population genomics studies also presents challenges. While LRS has proven valuable for individual genome analysis, scaling up to population-level studies requires further improvements in throughput and cost-effectiveness. Efforts are underway to develop protocols for multiplexing and targeted sequencing to address these limitations (Gilpatrick et al., 2020).In conclusion, long-read DNA sequencing has ushered in a new era of genomic research, offering unprecedented insights into genome structure, variation, and function. As the technology continues to evolve and mature, it promises to further our understanding of human genetics and improve the diagnosis and treatment of genetic disorders. However, addressing the remaining challenges in accuracy, cost, and scalability will be crucial for realizing the full potential of LRS in both research and clinical applications.
